<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The weighted average expected life of the option
grants was estimated based on historical exercise patterns. For
1999, volatility for McAfee.com was estimated based on the
weighted average volatility of five public companies in similar
business to McAfee.com. McAfee.com has not paid a dividend and
has no plans to do so.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The weighted average grant date fair value of
options granted by McAfee.com to employees in 2001 and 2000 were
$8.44 and $17.54, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company and McAfee.com have also estimated
the fair value of purchase rights issued under their employee
stock purchase plans. Rights under these plans were also valued
using the Black-Scholes option pricing model. Parameters for the
purchase rights analysis are listed below:
</FONT>

authorized the Company to repurchase

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">additional common stock of up to
$50.0&nbsp;million in the open market. Through December&nbsp;31,
2001, the Company repurchased 5.0&nbsp;million shares of its
common stock bringing total cash outlay to date to approximately
$112.9&nbsp;million. The timing and size of any future stock
repurchases are subject to market conditions, stock prices, the
Company&#146;s cash position and other cash requirements. Such
repurchases are intended to cover the Company&#146;s reissuances
under the Employee Stock Purchase Plan (ESPP), the 1997 Plan,
and issuances related to potential mergers and acquisitions.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On August&nbsp;2, 1999, February&nbsp;16, 2000
and May&nbsp;31, 2000, the Company sold &#147;European
style&#148; put options for 3&nbsp;million shares of the
Company&#146;s common stock as part of its stock repurchase
plan. On August&nbsp;3, 2000, put options sold on August&nbsp;2,
1999 for 1.0&nbsp;million shares were exercised in the
Company&#146;s stock. In February 2001, the Company settled the
remaining put options, which resulted in the purchase of
2.0&nbsp;million shares of the Company&#146;s stock for
approximately $53.8&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
	<TD width="3%"></TD>
	<TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
	<TD></TD>
	<TD>
	<B><I><FONT size="2">Preferred Shares Rights
	Agreement</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On October&nbsp;19, 1998, pursuant to a Preferred
Shares Rights Agreement between the Company and BankBoston, N.A.
as Rights Agent, the Board of Directors of the Company announced
that it had declared a dividend distribution of one preferred
share purchase right (a &#147;Right&#148;) on each outstanding
share of the Company&#146;s common stock. Each Right will
entitle stockholders to buy one one-thousandth of a share of the
Company&#146;s Series&nbsp;B Participating Preferred Stock at an
exercise price of $200.00. The Rights will become exercisable
following the tenth day after a person or group announces the
acquisition of 15% or more of the Company&#146;s common stock or
announces commencement of a tender or exchange offer, the
consummation of which would result in ownership by the person or
group of 15% or more of the common stock of the Company. The
Company will be entitled to redeem the Rights at $0.01 per Right
at any time on or before the tenth day following acquisition by
a person or group of 15% or more of the Company&#146;s common
stock. The dividend distribution was made on November&nbsp;3,
1998, payable to the stockholders of record on November&nbsp;3,
1998. The Rights will expire on October&nbsp;20, 2008.
</FONT>

<P align="left">

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">78
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Realization of net deferred tax assets of
$200.1&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2001 is dependent on
generating sufficient future taxable income, which is not
assured. The amount of the deferred tax asset realizable,
however, could be reduced in the near term if estimates of
future taxable income are reduced. A valuation allowance has
been recorded as a result of uncertainties related to the
deferred tax asset realization.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2001, the Company has
available net operating loss carry-forwards for income tax
purposes of approximately $50.3&nbsp;million; U.S.&nbsp;federal
losses of approximately $40.2&nbsp;million, which expire from
2009 to 2021, and foreign losses of approximately
$10.1&nbsp;million, which have no expiration.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">U.S. income taxes were not provided for on a
cumulative total of approximately $25.2&nbsp;million of
undistributed earnings for certain non-U.S. subsidiaries. The
Company intends to reinvest these earnings indefinitely in
operations outside the United States.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company&#146;s effective tax rate on income
before income taxes differs from the U.S. Federal statutory
regular tax rate as follows:
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="80%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
	<TD width="68%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD colspan="11"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD colspan="11" align="center" nowrap><B><FONT size="1">Years Ended December 31,</FONT></B></TD>

</TR>

<TR>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD colspan="3" align="center" nowrap><B><FONT size="1">2001</FONT></B></TD>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD colspan="3" align="center" nowrap><B><FONT size="1">2000</FONT></B></TD>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD colspan="3" align="center" nowrap><B><FONT size="1">1999</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD colspan="3" align="center" nowrap><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD colspan="3" align="center" nowrap><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD colspan="3" align="center" nowrap><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#EEEEEE">
	<TD align="left" valign="top">
	<DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px">
	<FONT size="2">U.S. Federal income tax benefit at statutory rate
	</FONT></DIV>
	</TD>
	<TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">(35.0</FONT></TD>
	<TD align="left" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">)%</FONT></TD>
	<TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">(35.0</FONT></TD>
	<TD align="left" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">)%</FONT></TD>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The tax benefit associated with stock option
exercises from employee stock plans reduced taxes currently
payable for 2001 by $5.4&nbsp;million. Such benefit was recorded
to additional paid-in capital.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">79
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">80
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">15.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Business
Segment and Major Customer Information</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company has concluded that it has two
businesses consisting of the Infrastructure business
(&#147;Infrastructure&#148;) and McAfee.com. The Infrastructure
business markets and sells computer security, management and
availability software and hardware for corporate and government
users. McAfee.com markets and sells PC security and management
software on the Internet to consumers and small to medium-sized
businesses. Management measures profitability based on these two
businesses; however, within the Infrastructure business the
Company&#146;s operating segments are defined by six geographic
regions. The segments are evidence of the operating structure of
the Company&#146;s internal organization. The Company operates
in one industry: computer security, management, and availability
software, hardware and related services for, primarily,
corporate and government users.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Infrastructure business markets and sells,
through its geographic segments, anti-virus and security
software, hardware and services; network management software,
hardware and services; and help desk software and services.
These products and services are marketed and sold through a
direct sales force to corporate and government users, as well
as, through resellers, distributors, systems integrators and
retailers, worldwide. In addition, the Infrastructure business
includes managed security and availability applications to
corporations and governments on the Internet.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">McAfee.com is an application service provider
targeted at consumers and small to medium-sized businesses. The
McAfee.com web site provides a suite of online products and
services personalized for the user based on the user&#146;s PC
configuration, attached peripherals and resident software.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Following is the summary of the Company&#146;s
revenue and operating income (losses) by business and by
geographic segment. The accounting policies of the businesses
and geographic segments are the same as disclosed in Note&nbsp;2
to these Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. To
reconcile to the consolidated financial statements, where
applicable, &#147;Corporate&#148; represents costs and expenses
associated with corporate activities. Corporate activities
include general and administrative expenses; corporate marketing
expenses of $40.4&nbsp;million and $46.1 million in 2001 and
2000, respectively; amortization of intangibles; stock-based
compensation charges; and acquisition, restructuring and other
related costs. These corporate expenses are not considered
attributable to any specific geographic segment. Summarized
financial information concerning the
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">81
</FONT>

</CENTER>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Net revenue and operating expenses for geographic
segments are not presented for 1999 as it is impracticable to do
so. However, 1999 net revenues for the Infrastructure business
and McAfee.com were $659.2&nbsp;million and $24.5&nbsp;million,
respectively, and 1999 operating losses for the Infrastructure
business and McAfee.com were $109.9&nbsp;million and
$28.3&nbsp;million, respectively. For 1999, revenue by domestic
(United States) and international amounted to
$406.8&nbsp;million and $276.9&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Following is a summary of the Company&#146;s
long-lived assets and total assets by business and by geographic
segment. Long-lived assets are capital expenditures, including
land purchases, and do not include intangibles. Assets purchased
to support Infrastructure general and administrative activities,
including land purchases, are included in &#147;Corporate&#148;
in the &#147;Long-lived assets&#148; table below. Assets
purchased to support Infrastructure general and administrative
activities, including land purchases, and Infrastructure
intangibles are included in &#147;Corporate&#148; in the
&#147;Total assets&#148; table, below. These corporate assets
are not assigned to any specific
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">82
</FONT>

accounts receivable balance greater than 10% of the

December&nbsp;31, 2000, two customers had accounts receivable
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">83
</FONT>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">balances greater than 10% of the Company&#146;s
total accounts receivable balance. During 2001 and 2000, one
customer accounted for 27% and 20%, respectively, of the total
revenue for each year. The revenue derived from this customer is
reported in the Infrastructure business, mainly in the United
States and Europe segments. No customer accounted for more than
10% of the total revenue in 1999.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">During 2001, 2000 and 1999, the Company sold
receivables aggregating approximately zero, $12.7&nbsp;million
and $48.0&nbsp;million, respectively. These receivables were
sold at a customary discount of up to 3.5% of face amount
without recourse to the Company. The discounts were recorded as
an operating expense. As of December&nbsp;31, 2000 and 1999, no
receivables sold in 2000 or 1999, as applicable, remained
outstanding.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">16.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Litigation</FONT></B>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
	<TD width="3%"></TD>
	<TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
	<TD></TD>
	<TD>
	<B><I><FONT size="2">General</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">From time to time, the Company has been subject
to litigation including the pending litigation described below.
The Company&#146;s current estimated range of liability related
to some of the pending litigation below is based on claims for
which management can estimate the amount and range of loss. The
Company has recorded the minimum estimated liability related to
those claims, where there is a range of loss. Because of the
uncertainties related to both the amount and range of loss on
the remaining pending litigation, management is unable to make a
reasonable estimate of the liability that could result from an
unfavorable outcome. As additional information becomes
available, the Company will assess its potential liability and
revise its estimates. Pending or future litigation could be
costly, could cause the diversion of management&#146;s attention
and could upon resolution, have a material adverse effect on the
our business, results of operations, financial condition and
cash flow.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In addition, the Company is engaged in certain
legal and administrative proceedings incidental to our normal
business activities and believes that these matters will not
have a material adverse effect on our financial position,
results of operations or cash flow.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
	<TD width="3%"></TD>
	<TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
	<TD></TD>
	<TD>
	<B><I><FONT size="2">Securities Cases</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Between December&nbsp;29, 2000 and
February&nbsp;7, 2001, the Company and certain of its current
and former officers and directors were named in securities class
action lawsuits filed in the United States District Court for
the Northern District of California. On September&nbsp;24, 2001,
a consolidated class action complaint was filed which asserts
claims against the Company, William Larson, Prabhat Goyal and
Peter Watkins on behalf of a putative class of persons who
purchased the Company&#146;s stock between July&nbsp;19 and
December&nbsp;26, 2000. The complaint assert causes of action
(and seeks unspecified damages) for alleged violations of
Exchange Act Section&nbsp;10(b)/SEC Rule&nbsp;10b-5 and Exchange
Act Section&nbsp;20(a). In particular, the complaint alleges
that defendants engaged in improper practices designed to
increase the Company&#146;s revenues and earnings and that, as a
result of those practices, the Company&#146;s class period
financial statements were false and misleading and failed to
comply with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP).
Defendants&#146; filed a motion to dismiss plaintiff&#146;s
consolidated complaint on October&nbsp;29, 2001 and plaintiff
filed its opposition to the motion to dismiss on
December&nbsp;21, 2001.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On February&nbsp;5, 2001, the Company was
nominally sued in a derivative lawsuit filed in the Superior
Court in Santa Clara County. The lawsuit, encaptioned <I>Mean
Ann Krim v.&nbsp;William L. Larson, et al</I>., Case
No.&nbsp;CV795734, asserts claims against William Larson, Peter
Watkins, Prabhat Goyal, Leslie Denend, Virginia Gemmell, Edwin
Harper, Enzo Torresi, and others for breach of fiduciary duty,
unjust enrichment. In particular, the complaints allege that the
defendants engaged in a course of conduct by which they
improperly accounted for revenue from software license sales,
and that, as a result of their actions, certain of the
Company&#146;s financial statements were false and misleading
and not in compliance with GAAP. The complaint seeks an
unspecified amount of damages. Nominal defendant the Company
filed a demurrer to the complaint
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">84
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">on May&nbsp;21, 2001. A hearing on the demurrer
was held on June&nbsp;29, 2001. On July&nbsp;24, 2001, the Court
sustained the demurrer with leave to amend. By Order dated
August&nbsp;21, 2001, the Court granted plaintiff limited
discovery for purposes of amending the complaint to meet the
demand futility test imposed by Delaware law. The Court&#146;s
Order set a deadline of October&nbsp;26, 2001 for the filing of
the amended complaint. On December&nbsp;26, 2001, plaintiff
filed an amended complaint. By stipulation, nominal defendant
the Company&#146;s demurrer is due on January&nbsp;30, 2002.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
	<TD width="3%"></TD>
	<TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
	<TD></TD>
	<TD>
	<B><I><FONT size="2">Other Litigation</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Crawford v. Digital River, Inc. et al., Case
No.&nbsp;1:01CV01770 RWR; United States District Court, District
of Columbia.</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> On August&nbsp;21, 2001,
Christopher Crawford filed a complaint for patent infringement
of US&nbsp;Patent 6,014,651. The complaint alleges that seven
different defendants, including the Company, infringe
US&nbsp;Patent 6,014,651. The complaint alleges that the Company
infringes the patent through several web sites, including the
websites at www.nai.com and www.mcafee.com. The Company answered
the complaint on September&nbsp;12, 2001 in which the alleged
patent infringement was denied. The other defendants have
answered the complaint. An initial scheduling conference is
scheduled for November&nbsp;27, 2001, and prior to that date,
counsel for plaintiff and defendants will meet and confer
according to the court&#146;s rules.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Foremost Systems v. Network Associates,
No.&nbsp;CV 777301 (Santa Clara
County).</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> A former agent of the Company
in India, Foremost Systems Pvt. Ltd., filed this action on
October&nbsp;14, 1998, in California State court and filed a
Second Amended Complaint on February&nbsp;18, 2000. The Company
removed the action to the United States District Court, Northern
District of California, San Jose Division. The Second Amended
Complaint alleges that the Company wrongly terminated Foremost
Systems in breach of their agency agreement and, in addition,
contains counts for breach of oral contract, promissory
estoppel, intentional and negligent misrepresentation, breach of
fiduciary duty, tortious interference with contractual
relations, unfair competition, and racketeering in violation of
18&nbsp;U.S.C. 1962 et&nbsp;seq. The parties held a preliminary
mediation session in this matter on April&nbsp;5, 2000 and
attended a full session on March&nbsp;12, 2001. Discovery is
ongoing.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">ESniff.</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> On
June&nbsp;5, 2001, eSniff, Inc. (&#147;eSniff&#148;) filed a
complaint in U.S.&nbsp;District Court for the District of
Colorado, Case No.&nbsp;01-D-1024, seeking a declaratory
judgment that its use of the ESNIFF trade name and trademark
does not infringe the Company&#146;s SNIFFER mark. On
June&nbsp;13, 2001, the Company and Networks Associates
Technology, Inc. filed a complaint in the U.S.&nbsp;District
Court in the Northern District of California, Case
No.&nbsp;C01-20537 PVT, against eSniff for trademark
infringement, trademark dilution, and unfair competition under
federal and California state law related to use of the ESNIFF
name and mark. On November&nbsp;26, 2001, while both motions
were pending, the parties reached a settlement of both lawsuits.
As part of the settlement, eSniff acknowledged that SNIFFER is a
strong, famous, and distinctive mark and agreed to discontinue
its use of ESNIFF.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Homenexus Inc. f/k/a HomeRun Network, Inc. v.
DirectWeb, Inc., et al, No.&nbsp;99-CV-2316 (CRW) (E.D.
Pa.).</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> In this action, filed in federal
court in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania on May&nbsp;5,
1999, plaintiff Homenexus alleges that DirectWeb successfully
conspired with all defendants, including the Company and William
Larson, to wrongly misappropriate plaintiff&#146;s purported
proprietary business plan and to deliberately infringe
plaintiff&#146;s purported trade dress in its alleged web-site.
The complaint further alleges that all defendants conspired to
commit, and did commit, the torts of conversion and unfair
competition. Plaintiff filed an amended complaint on
June&nbsp;21, 2000, adding a new defendant, Riaz Karamali.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">17.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Related Party
Transactions</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company purchased 3,948,199 shares of
Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock of DirectWeb, Inc. for
$2.5&nbsp;million, and 4,615,385 shares of Series&nbsp;B
Preferred Stock for $6.0&nbsp;million in 1999. In connection
with the formation of DirectWeb, the Company received a warrant
to acquire 3,175,000&nbsp;shares of DirectWeb common stock for
total consideration of $317.50. Prior to the transactions
described below, on an as converted basis and
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">85
</FONT>

<P><HR noshade><P>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">excluding shares that may be acquired upon
exercise of its warrant, the Company&#146;s total DirectWeb
investment represented approximately 12.3% of DirectWeb&#146;s
outstanding capital stock. With respect to this balance,
approximately 35.2% was owned by William&nbsp;L. Larson, a
DirectWeb founder and the Company&#146;s former Chief Executive
Officer; 35.4% was owned by Dennis Cline, a DirectWeb founder
and the Company&#146;s former Vice President of Worldwide Sales;
and 17.1% was owned by unrelated third party investors who,
along with the Company, invested in DirectWeb&#146;s
Series&nbsp;A and Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In November 1999, the Company sold its 12.3%
ownership to Dennis Cline, resulting in a net loss of
$2.5&nbsp;million to the Company. At the time, the Company also
agreed to exchange its warrant to acquire 3,175,000&nbsp;shares
of DirectWeb common stock for a warrant to acquire
$2&nbsp;million worth of DirectWeb Series&nbsp;C preferred stock
at the same price per share as paid by the Series&nbsp;C
preferred stock investors. William&nbsp;L. Larson sold
approximately 83.0% of his stake in DirectWeb to Dennis Cline in
November 1999. He retained an approximately 5.9% ownership
interest in DirectWeb.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">18.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock-Based
Compensation</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company has recorded stock based compensation
charges of $24.7&nbsp;million, $8.7&nbsp;million and
$15.6&nbsp;million in 2001, 2000 and 1999 respectively.
Stock-based compensation charges relate to the repricing of
employee stock options and the issuance of McAfee.com stock
options to the Company&#146;s executives and employees, as well
as non-recurring stock compensation charges primarily related to
executive compensation.
</FONT>

the following for the years presented (in thousands):

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I><FONT size="2">Repriced options.
</FONT></I></B><FONT size="2">On April&nbsp;22, 1999, the
Company offered to substantially all of its employees, excluding
executive officers, the right to cancel certain outstanding
stock options and receive new options with an exercise price of
$11.063, the then current fair market value of the stock.
Options to purchase a total of 10.3&nbsp;million shares were
cancelled and the same number of new options were granted. These
new options vest at the same rate that they would have vested
under previous option plans and are subject to variable
accounting. Accordingly, the Company has and will continue to
remeasure compensation cost for the repriced options until these
options are exercised, canceled, or forfeited without
replacement. The first valuation period began July&nbsp;1, 2000.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Subsequent to April&nbsp;22, 1999, some
employees, who received repriced options became employees of
McAfee.com. In connection with this transfer their repriced
options were canceled and replaced with options for McAfee.com
stock. Variable plan accounting as described above, also applies
to these replacement options and variable charges will be
recorded based on the movements in the fair value of McAfee.com
common stock from July&nbsp;1, 2000.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The amount of stock compensation recorded has and
will be based on any excess of the closing stock price at the
end of the reporting period or date of exercise, forfeiture or
cancellation without replacement, if
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">86
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">earlier, over the fair value of the
Company&#146;s or McAfee.com&#146;s common stock on July&nbsp;1,
2000, which was $20.375 and $26.063, respectively. The resulting
compensation charge to earnings will be recorded over the
remaining vesting period, using the accelerated method of
amortization discussed in FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;28,
&#147;Accounting for Stock Appreciation Rights and Other
Variable Stock Option or Award Plans.&#148; When options are
fully vested, the charge will be recorded to earnings
immediately. At December&nbsp;31, 2001 these options are
substantially fully vested. Depending upon movements in the
market value of the Company&#146;s common stock, this accounting
treatment may result in significant additional stock-based
compensation charges in future periods.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">During 2001 and 2000, the Company incurred
charges to earnings of approximately $15.6&nbsp;million and
$2.0&nbsp;million related to options subject to variable plan
accounting. For 2001 and 2000, the Company&#146;s stock
compensation charges related to options subject to variable plan
accounting were based on a year end per share price of the
Company&#146;s stock of $25.85 and $4.19, respectively and a per
share price of McAfee.com stock of $33.91 and $5.00,
respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2001 the Company and
McAfee.com had options to purchase 2.2&nbsp;million shares and
0.2&nbsp;million shares respectively, which were outstanding and
subject to variable plan accounting.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company also incurred a stock-based
compensation charge in connection with the initial issuance of
the repriced options. This charge was calculated based on the
difference between the exercise price of the new options and
their market value on the date of acceptance by employees.
Approximately $1.8&nbsp;million, $6.7&nbsp;million and
$8.8&nbsp;million was expensed during 2001, 2000 and 1999,
respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I><FONT size="2">McAfee.com options and shares issued to
Network Associates personnel.
</FONT></I></B><FONT size="2">During 1999, McAfee.com granted
1.7&nbsp;million options to purchase shares of its Class&nbsp;A
common stock and 379,000&nbsp;shares of its Class&nbsp;A common
stock to executives and employees of Network Associates. In
connection with these grants, McAfee.com recorded a stock based
compensation charge of $6.7&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I><FONT size="2">Warrants to outside consultants.
</FONT></I></B><FONT size="2">In January 2001, upon completion
of the search for the Company&#146;s chief executive officer,
the Company issued warrants to a retained executive search firm
for services performed. The warrants, if exercised, can be
exchanged for 166,667 shares of the Company&#146;s common stock.
The weighted-average exercise price of the underlying shares is
$2.97 per share. The warrants are immediately exercisable and
expire in January 2004. The combined fair value of the warrants
was determined to be approximately $530,000 and was estimated
using the Black-Scholes model with the following assumptions:
risk free interest rate of 4.82%; contractual life of
3&nbsp;years; dividend yield of 0%; and expected volatility of
91%. The fair market value of the warrants was included as stock
compensation during 2001 and included in general and
administrative expenses in the accompanying statement of
operations.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In April 2001, upon completion of the search for
the Company&#146;s chief financial officer, the Company issued
warrants to a retained executive search firm for services
performed. The warrants, if exercised, can be exchanged for
66,667 shares of the Company&#146;s common stock. The
weighted-average exercise price of the underlying shares is
$4.50 per share. The warrants are immediately exercisable and
expire in April 2004. The combined fair value of the warrants
was determined to be approximately $280,000 and was estimated
using the Black-Scholes model with the following assumptions:
risk free interest rate of 4.27%; contractual life of
3&nbsp;years; dividend yield of 0%; and expected volatility of
91%. The fair market value of the warrants was included as a
stock compensation charge during 2001 and included in general
and administrative expenses in the accompanying statement of
operations.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In November 2001, upon completion of the search
for two executives for international operations, the Company
issued warrants to a retained executive search firm for services
performed. The warrants, if exercised, can be exchanged for
20,833&nbsp;shares of the Company&#146;s common stock. The
weighted-average exercise price of the underlying shares is
$19.64 per share. The warrants are immediately exercisable and
expire in 2004. The combined fair value of the warrants was
determined to be approximately $239,000 and was
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">87
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">estimated using the Black-Scholes model with the
following assumptions: risk free interest rate of 4.36%;
contractual life of 3&nbsp;years; dividend yield of 0%; and
expected volatility of 84%. The fair market value of the
warrants was included as a stock compensation charge during 2001
and included in general and administrative expenses in the
accompanying statement of operations.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">All the above warrants have been included in
Stockholders&#146; Equity.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I><FONT size="2">Former executives.
</FONT></I></B><FONT size="2">In January 2001, the
Company&#146;s board of directors appointed the Company&#146;s
new chief executive officer and president. Effective January
2001, the Company&#146;s former chief executive officer, former
chief financial officer, and former president and chief
operating officer, became special advisors. Options held by
these individuals continue to vest during 2001 while they each
served during their one-year terms as special advisors. As a
result, the Company recorded a one-time stock compensation
charge of approximately $603,000 during 2001.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In December 2001, the Company terminated the
employment of three sales executives. Upon termination, the
options held by these executives were modified. As a result, the
Company recorded a one-time stock compensation charge of
$2.1&nbsp;million during 2001.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I><FONT size="2">New executives.
</FONT></I></B><FONT size="2">On January&nbsp;3, 2001, the
Company entered into an employment agreement with George Samenuk
to become the Company&#146;s chief executive officer. In
accordance with the terms of the agreement, the Company issued
400,000&nbsp;shares of restricted stock to Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk. The
price of the underlying shares is $0.01 per share. The shares
will vest and the Company&#146;s right to repurchase such shares
will lapse as follows: 12.5% on the first four quarterly
anniversaries of Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s employment with the
Company with the remaining 50% on the second year anniversary of
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s employment with the Company. The fair
value of the restricted stock was determined to be approximately
$1.7&nbsp;million and was estimated based on the difference
between the exercise price of the restricted stock and the fair
market value of the Company&#146;s common stock on
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s employment commencement date. During
2001, the Company recorded approximately $836,000 related to
stock compensation associated with Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s
restricted stock.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On April&nbsp;3, 2001 the Company entered into an
employment agreement with Stephen&nbsp;C. Richards to become
executive vice president and chief financial officer. In
accordance with the terms of the agreement, the Company issued
50,000 shares of common stock to Mr.&nbsp;Richards for $0.01 per
share. During 2001, the Company recorded approximately $350,000
related to stock compensation associated with
Mr.&nbsp;Richards&#146; stock.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On October&nbsp;30, 2001 the Company entered into
an employment agreement with Arthur&nbsp;R. Matin to become
executive the president of the Company&#146;s McAfee product
group. In accordance with the terms of the agreement, the
Company issued 100,000&nbsp;shares of common stock to
Mr.&nbsp;Matin for $0.01 per share. During 2001, the Company
recorded approximately $1.9&nbsp;million related to stock
compensation associated with Mr.&nbsp;Matin&#146;s stock.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<B><I><FONT size="2">PGP restructuring.
</FONT></I></B><FONT size="2">In connection with the integration
of the PGP product group the Company accelerated the vesting of
45,600 options to purchase the Company&#146;s common stock held
by the 100&nbsp;employees terminated during 2001. As a result of
this modification, the Company recorded a stock based
compensation charge of $519,000 within restructuring expense in
the statement of operations. The charge was calculated based on
the intrinsic value of the modified options on the date the
acceleration was approved by the Board of Directors. (See
Note&nbsp;7 to these Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements).
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">19.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fixed Assets
Sale-Leaseback</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On September&nbsp;20, 1999, the Company sold
approximately $6.5&nbsp;million of fixed assets, consisting
mostly of computer equipment, to a third party and leased them
back under an operating lease. The initial term of the
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">88
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">lease is 12 months, with an option to renew the
lease for an additional 12&nbsp;months. In October 2000, the
Company repurchased the fixed assets for approximately $5.2
million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">20.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent
Events</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On January&nbsp;15, 2002, the Company&#146;s
board of directors approved a grant of 50,000&nbsp;shares of
restricted stock to George Samenuk, the Company&#146;s chief
executive officer. The price of the underlying shares is $0.01
per share. The Company&#146;s right to repurchase such shares
will lapse on January&nbsp;15, 2005. The fair value of the
restricted stock was determined to be approximately $1.4 million
and was estimated based on the difference between the exercise
price of the restricted stock and the fair market value of the
Company&#146;s common stock on January&nbsp;15, 2002. This
amount will be recorded as compensation expense over the period
the Company&#146;s right to repurchase lapses.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">89

</CENTER>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">(1)&nbsp;<B><I>Provision for Doubtful Accounts,
Net.</I></B> The provision for doubtful accounts, net consists
of our estimates with respect to the uncollectability of our
receivables, net of recoveries of amounts previously written
off. Our management must make estimates of the uncollectability
of our accounts receivables. Management specifically analyzes
accounts receivable and analyzes historical bad debts, customer
concentrations, customer credit-worthiness, current economic
trends and changes in our customer payment terms when evaluating
the adequacy of the allowance for doubtful accounts. Our
accounts receivable balance was $136.4&nbsp;million, net of
allowance for doubtful accounts of $8.4&nbsp;million as of
December&nbsp;31, 2001.
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="40%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="8%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="8%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
	<TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
	<TD colspan="2"></TD>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD colspan="3"></TD>
	<TD></TD>
	<TD colspan="3" align="center" nowrap><B><FONT size="1">Provision for</FONT></B></TD>
	<TD></TD>

</CENTER>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">(2)&nbsp;<B><I>Provision for Sales Returns and
Allowances.</I></B> The provision for sales returns and
allowances consists of our estimates of potential future product
returns related to current period product revenue, and specific
provisions for distributor, reseller, and retailer sales
incentives (&#147;allowances&#148;) that are reductions in the
revenue to be realized. Management analyzes historical returns,
current economic trends, and changes in customer demand and
acceptance of our products when evaluating the adequacy of the
sales returns and allowances. Significant management judgments
and estimates must be made and used in connection with
establishing the sales returns and allowances in any accounting
period. Material differences may result in the amount and timing
of our revenue for any period if management made different
judgments or utilized different estimates. The provision for
sales returns and allowances amounted to $125.9&nbsp;million in
2001. The balance at December&nbsp;31, 2001, of
$32.6&nbsp;million includes the estimate of potential future
product returns amounting to $9.3&nbsp;million and specific
allowances for distributor, reseller, and retailer sales
incentives amounting to $23.3&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">91
</FONT>
